title: 90% of the problems caused by assassins are from their animations
body:
And by animations, I mean animation cancelling. That's 90% of what makes assassins broken because of how much extra damage they can stuff into an extra tiny timeframe.

That's why a good LeBlanc will nuke you with next to no mercy or fair time to react.

Or Talon/Rengar with their 100-0 combos in less than half a second.

And then you have Yasuo and Riven who are the poster children for how animation cancelling triples a champions skillcap by quadrupling their damage output. No really, Yasuo can wall mid-Q, Q mid-E (to be fair this one is intentional), wall mid-E, and wall mid-ult. Yasuo should be vulnerable during his ultimate but because of how he can cancel animations he's a lot more oppressive and safe than he should be.

I can guarantee you if something is done to restrict the amount of actions that can be completed during a leap, while projectiles are in the air, or while you're completing a self CC movement, assassins can be buffed to be playable without being good solely due to a hilariously frustrating mechanic.

Most champions can cancel _some_ of them, most assassins tho can cast full rotation in timeframe shorter than ordinary cast time.

Animation cancelling has always really annoyed me when it's central to a champion's gameplay, because you're basically abusing game mechanics that don't work properly, and because it means that mastery on those champions comes from reducing their counterplay rather than from knowledge of the champion and matchups.

It's not really possible to get rid of it, but if I were to redesign the game from scratch I think it'd be much better if animation cancelling didn't exist and champions who relied on it could demonstrate skill in other ways.

Definitely agree that it's the biggest problem with assassins, too.

The solution was present way back in 2010 when i started playing - practically every skill had a hilariously small channel time. You can still see it on a lot of older champs, but that leads to a whole host of other un-fun things.

It's an exaggeration, but Yasuo can increase his dps by a significant amount by cancelling autos and dealing deceptively more damage than he should.

Every champ can do that. Yasuo's q is a spell, and auto attacks do not lock out spells. If they did, it would feel shitty for everyone, even mages. 

Yasuo's q spell mimics an auto, but it is still a spell, so the "canceling" should not be removed.

He's also capable of using both Q and W almost instantaneously as well as E and W. Yasuo's issue is that whenever he does something particularly ballsy he is not adequately punished for it due to his animation cancelling. Q plays a part in it but honestly it's when he uses his E/R and isn't locked out of his Q/W that is the problem.

Like, what is the point of making a champ that puts yourself in the middle of a team if the champ has no inherent risk due to an unintended interaction (being able to use W halfway through your animation).

He actually can't cancel his e into q. He can only buffer his q, which is activated at the end of the e animation. it seems like most of your frustration is him being able to use w quickly after his other spells. 

Melee ADCs need reliable, reactionary defensive tools in order to be viable. They are squishy in the middle of a teamfight, and would be useless if their kits were too unforgiving. Yi has alpha popping and meditate. Trynd has timed invulnerability (though he is not as good). Yas needs his w and passive to not get blown up, and as a spell-intensive character he needs to use them when he intends to. Otherwise he would just be clunky and literally no one would play him because not only would he feel bad, he would actually be bad.
